newsitem.title: INDIA: India cotton prices ease after truck strike ends.
newsitem.headline: India cotton prices ease after truck strike ends.

text.p: Fresh supplies of cotton began arriving at Indian markets on Friday, following the end of a 10-day truck strike, pushed prices lower as mill buying remained low in anticipation of heavier arrivals to come.
"Earlier in the week arrivals remained low on account of a nationwide truck strike but now arrivals have picked up again," dealers said.
Truckers called off their strike on Wednesday evening, and the stoppage lasted another day in the western state of Maharashtra.
Low arrivals during the strike drove prices higher, but millers back off in anticipation of a surge in arivals once the trucks started rolling again.

In spot deals Bengal-deshi slid by 10 rupees at 900/940 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) while Punjab saw-ginned moved down by 5/15 rupees at 1,545/1,645 rupees per maund. Gujarat Kalyan (medium-staple) fell by 200/300 rupees at 13,500/13,800 rupees per candy (355.56 kg) while superior variety of the Gujarat Sankar-4 (long-staple) moved down by 400/500 rupees at 18,500/19,500 rupees per candy.
Limited overseas enquiries for cotton and yarn also subdued the market sentiments at the close of the session.
